fields.label_text:
COCONUT CUP
Mounted in silver-gilt.
Inscribed: "THE LOUIS ERASMUS & MARQUESE D'ANTIN TAKEN Ye 10 JULY 1745 LAT 43d 5 On CHARLES ROGER BROKER."
About 1745
W. T. Johnson Bequest.
M.1658-1944

fields.descriptive_line: Carved, polished coconut mounted in silver, on a silver foot with silver handles, Spanish or Viceroyalty of Peru, about 1745.
fields.physical_description: Nut, polished and carved, mounted in silver as a two-handled cup.
fields.dimensions: Height: 11 cm Base to rim, Diameter: 6.2 cm Across rim, Diameter: 7.1 cm Across foot
fields.label:
COCONUT CUP
Mounted in silver-gilt.
Inscribed: "THE LOUIS ERASMUS & MARQUESE D'ANTIN TAKEN Ye 10 JULY 1745 LAT 43d 5 On CHARLES ROGER BROKER."
About 1745
W. T. Johnson Bequest.
M.1658-1944 [1970-1990]
fields.marks:
Engraved round the rim of the cup, in English:
'The Louis Erasmus & Marquese D'Antin taken y<sup>e</sup> 10 July 1745. Lat. 43<sup>d</sup>. 50<sup>m</sup>. Charles Rogers Broker'
fields.bibliography:
Christie's London, Sale 6354, 5 July 2000, lot 21.
<u>The Gentleman's Magazine</u>, August 1745, vol. 15, pp. 418 and 428.
Describes the number of guns and valuable cargo aboard the two ships.
fields.credit: Bequeathed by W. J. Johnson, Esq.
fields.history_note: The 'Louis Erasmus' and the 'Marquese D'Antin' were two French ships captured by the English during the War of the Spanish Succession, and this mounted coconut cup was part of the treasure recovered from them. A short letter by 'J.S.' on the successful capture of the ships published in the August 1745 issue of <u>The Gentleman's Magazine</u> explains that 'these ships went out four years ago to Peru and Chili, and had on board [...] one million sterling in gold and silver coin, besides 800 tons of cocoa, and we are every day discovering more treasure that has been concealed' (pp. 428-9). The V&A cup is not the only piece to survive from the haul. In 2000, a silver-gilt basin with a similar inscription was auctioned at Christie's, London (sale 6354, lot 21). The English did not manage to capture all the treasure, however.  'J.S.' recalls that there were numerous friars aboard the ships, 'one of whom threw a gold chalice into the sea of great value that it should not come into our hands' (p. 429).
